dict.string: She was born in a Catholic and wealthy family and had one older brother and one older sister.
During her travels, she used to collect leftover food from people on the plane and give it to hungry people.
She was fascinated with missionaries, and by the age of 12, knew that she would commit herself to a religious vocation.
She left home to join the Sisters of Loreto, based in Ireland, when she was 18, and never saw her mother again.
She was once scheduled to meet the Pope but postponed the meeting because she was too busy working with the poor.
Teresa was actually the second name she chose, she changed her original name because another nun already chosen it.
She taught history and geography in a girls' high school for 15 years, but was distressed by the poverty around her.
She was able to speak fluently in five different languages, including English, which she studied in Ireland for a year.
Some speculated that her father may have been poisoned to death because of his dedication to Albanian Independence.
With no income or supplies, she taught the children in the slums to read and write by writing in the dirt with sticks.
When awarded the Nobel in 1979, she refused the traditional banquet and asked that the funds be sent to India.
She was criticised for using her celebrity status to promote the Church's moral teachings on abortion and birth control.
